method.notes: Clusters derived via intersection of curated cancer pathway literature, glioblastoma transcriptome analyses, and experimental gene interaction data. Programs prioritized by recurrence in literature and pathway completeness.

programs.description: Key genes drive cytoskeletal remodeling, cell adhesion changes, and matrix degradation for GBM cell invasion. This program integrates ECM proteases (ADAMTS18, ADAM28, TGM2), cytoskeletal regulators (SEPTIN14, TRPV4), cell adhesion molecules (PCDH11X, CNTNAP2, DOCK2), matrix proteins (POSTN, COL12A1, COL19A1), and migration cues (RELN, SLIT2, WNT16). Notably, POSTN promotes macrophage recruitment and invasion, TGM2 is essential for survival and stemness during invasion, and TRPV4 facilitates F-actin dependent protrusions critical for migration.

citation.notes: POSTN directly promotes invasion via ECM remodeling in GBM
ADAMTS and TGM2 function in ECM breakdown and migration
TRPV4 drives F-actin invadopodia formation and migration
Integrins and CD44 mediate motor-clutch migration mode in GBM
RELN acts as a stop signal in neuronal migration; expression inversely correlates with GBM grade
SLIT2/ROBO pathway promotes immunosuppression and invasion
Voltage-gated ion channels and focal adhesions regulate GBM migration

predicted_cellular_impact: facilitated immune cell recruitment via POSTN
programs.evidence_summary: Multiple input genes converge on robust invasion/metastasis pathways (POSTN, ADAMTS, TRPV4, RELN, SLIT2) experimentally validated in glioblastoma and correlate with mesenchymal and invasive phenotypes.

citations.notes: POSTN as an invasion and macrophage chemoattractant in GBM
ECM and cytoskeletal regulation of GBM migration
TRPV4 and actin-dependent protrusion in GBM
RELN as a neuronal migration stop signal inversely correlated with GBM grade
SLIT2 pathway in immunosuppression and migration
Matrix metalloproteinases are critical ECM proteases in GBM not present in input
Integrin beta-1 and CD44 needed for adhesive migration

programs.description: A group of macrophage, microglia, and immunological regulatory genes (CD163, VSIG4, MSR1, INPP5D, IL7, CD96) cooperate in skewing the glioblastoma environment toward immune evasion. CD163, MSR1 and VSIG4 drive M2-like immunosuppressive macrophage phenotypes. INPP5D regulates myeloid cell signaling. CD96 acts as an NK cell/T cell checkpoint, and IL7 stimulation is epigenetically silenced, hampering adaptive immunity.

citation.notes: CD163 high levels correlate with immunosuppressive phenotype and poor prognosis
CD163 predicts poor survival and associates with immune checkpoints
CD96 acts as an immune checkpoint, correlates with infiltrating immune cells
Epigenetic suppression of IL7 pathway and T cell response in progressive GBM
INPP5D/SHIP1 modulates myeloid cell signaling, expressed in GBM microenvironment
CD163 found in intratumoral clusters of macrophages in GBM

programs.evidence_summary: CD163, VSIG4, and MSR1 coexpression drive immunosuppressive TAMs supported by high-grade glioma analyses; INPP5D and CD96 regulate myeloid and lymphoid checkpoints. IL7 pathway silencing intensifies T cell blockade.

citations.notes: Quantitative profiling of CD163 and immunosuppressive markers
CD163 enrichment predicts poor outcome
CD96 as immune checkpoint in GBM
IL7 pathway epigenetic suppression
INPP5D/SHIP1 role in myeloid signaling
Other checkpoints act with CD96 to modulate GBM immune response

programs.program_name: Glioblastoma Stem Cell Maintenance & Therapy Resistance
programs.description: Genes such as WNT16, ALDH1A2, HMGA2, BIRC3, and TGM2 join with pathways supporting stemness, therapy resistance, and tumor recurrence. WNT signaling drives stem cell self-renewal and radiotherapy resistance. ALDH1A2 and HMGA2 support stemness and expansion. BIRC3 enables apoptosis resistance and is directly tied to therapy adaptation. TGM2 links stemness, survival, and resistance in the mesenchymal GBM subtype.

citation.notes: WNT/β-catenin activation enables glioma stem cell proliferation and therapy resistance
WNT as a therapeutic resistance driver in GBM
ALDH1A2 upregulated in GBM, drives stem cell and therapy resistant subpopulations
HMGA2 promotes stemness, invasion and GBM tumorigenicity
BIRC3 as critical resistance factor in GBM apoptosis pathways
TGM2 drives mesenchymal transition, stemness and invasion in GBM
Calcium channels maintain stem cell niche

predicted_cellular_impact: increased tumor recurrence and therapy resistance
promotion of glioma stem-like cell self-renewal and proliferation
programs.evidence_summary: ALDH1A2, HMGA2, WNT16, BIRC3, TGM2 have direct functional links to therapy resistance, stemness and tumor recurrence in GBM. Targeting these genes impairs self-renewal and enhances therapy susceptibility.

citations.notes: WNT/β-catenin and resistance
Stem cell maintenance by ALDH1A2
HMGA2 as stemness and invasion driver
BIRC3 apoptosis evasion
TGM2 survival/stemness
SOX2 and STAT3 are key GSC regulators
CD44 necessary for TGM2-mediated stemness

programs.description: Core angiogenic and hypoxia-responsive genes (VEGFD, TEK, FAP, PLIN2) collaborate to drive neovascularization and metabolic reprogramming. VEGFD and TEK (TIE2) are critical endothelial regulators. FAP+ mesenchymal cells cooperate with endothelial cells and support pro-angiogenic microenvironment. PLIN2 and related lipid droplet proteins adapt GBM cells to hypoxic metabolic stress.

citation.notes: VEGF pathway as central driver of GBM angiogenesis
PLIN2 mediates lipid droplet regulation and hypoxia response
FAP+ mesenchymal cells promote angiogenesis in GBM

programs.evidence_summary: VEGFD, TEK, FAP, and PLIN2 collectively drive angiogenic and metabolic adaptation of GBM, supporting rapid tumor expansion under hypoxic stress. FAP+ mesenchymal cells are a key microenvironment contributor.

citations.notes: VEGF and angiogenesis in GBM
FAP+ cell role in tumor microenvironment and angiogenesis
PLIN2 and lipid metabolism adaptation
ANGPT2 is a FAP+ cell product
HILPDA is a hypoxia-induced lipid regulator
